practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase is crucial for your long-term success because it focuses on internalizing the fundamental syntax and control structures that form the bedrock of your Java knowledge. By dedicating your hours to repetitive but increasingly complex logic puzzles, you ensure that your brain stops struggling with where to put a curly brace and starts focusing on high-level problem-solving. This phase provides the necessary stability for your learning journey, preventing the frustration that often occurs when attempting advanced concepts without a solid grasp of the basics.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Solving logic-based coding exercises on platforms like Exercism or Codewars
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Manual debugging of intentionally broken code snippets to understand compiler errors

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Writing basic loops and conditional statements in a single class
difficulty_profile.challenging: Nested loops and manipulating multi-dimensional arrays without helper methods

objective: Zero syntax errors on first compile in 5 consecutive exercises
subjective: Less reliance on search engines for basic syntax

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase transitions your practice from linear procedural logic to the world of objects, where you will learn to model real-world entities using classes and interfaces. This shift is necessary because it mimics how professional software is built, requiring you to think about how different parts of your code interact and share data safely. By wrestling with inheritance and encapsulation, you are developing the architectural intuition needed to handle larger codebases without losing your sense of clarity or control over the application's flow.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Building a CLI-based application (e.g., Library Management System) focusing on class relationships
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Refactoring previous procedural code into an object-oriented structure

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Creating classes with private fields and public getters/setters
difficulty_profile.challenging: Implementing polymorphic behavior and choosing between interfaces and abstract classes

objective: Project code uses at least 3 distinct interacting classes
subjective: Feeling comfortable with the concept of 'state' vs 'behavior'
Intuition for when to create a new class

objective: Time spent debugging per hour of coding
Number of JUnit tests passing in personal projects
Lines of code reduced through proper OOP refactoring
subjective: Perceived difficulty of official Java documentation
Confidence in explaining code structure to a peer
Frequency of 'aha' moments regarding object interactions

architect_notes: The 6-hour weekly limit suggests a 1-hour daily session with one day off is better than one long session to combat syntax fatigue.
The transition to Cycle 2 should only occur when the user can write a for-loop and if-statement without checking a reference.
Focus is placed on IntelliJ IDEA shortcuts early to reduce the friction of typing Java's verbose syntax.

details.reason: User initiated a new learning session.

timeline.title: Initial Practice Strategy Created
timeline.summary: Initial practice strategy created for ['Learn Java'].

details.reason: Sufficient information provided to create initial practice system.

constraints.dropout_risk: Syntax frustration and conceptual overload in OOP
